If while teaching, a crucial definition comes up, it's one thing to say, "this is important".. Quite another to say it "will be on the exam"
Choice questions on exams are interesting: "Answer part a or part b. Do not answer both."
Most of the arguments I've heard against using exams, and in particular final exams, are actually arguments for changing the format of exams
Going to lead a brainstorming session this week on pros and cons of exams (vs other assessment). Would appreciate a head start. Cons anyone?

During Putnam, students may get the impression I'm enjoying the experience (of trying stuff) as much as they are; and I am, for all 6 hours.
Putnam math contests are usually designed to have a question where everyone can do that. So then it's about the experience, not the score.
Regarding Putnam, I advise: Pick one or two questions (per 3 hour session) and just explore it, ask related questions. Try stuff.
The Putnam Mathematical Competition is occasionally criticized for having questions that are too hard. But our students had a blast!
@mathsjem I don't think teachers of other subjects have that luxury. But we know that problem-solving skills help most aspects of life.
@mathsjem As a math teacher, I always believe I'm doing something good for my students; even if they don't end up in math.
@mathsjem I'm definitely not saying things would be perfect. But if everyone were a bit more thoughtful, lots of things should improve.
@mathsjem the effort required to understand mathematics (it's huge). So there would be a society of people more willing to think 1st.
@mathsjem All kinds of things will be done more efficiently. So we would have more wealth than otherwise. Also, one can't fake:
@mathsjem So in the short term, math teachers would immediately get huge raises and other teachers would lose their jobs. In the long term:
@mathsjem If *everyone* does a math degree, then we would be faced with an emergency shortage of math teachers;and surplus of other teachers
